choices.text: V Shaped Nicks on the Edge of the Nail

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with patchy non scarring hair loss over scalp with exclamation mark hairs at margins. Which of the following is the most likely expected nail finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nail Pitting

 

Option A:

 

  • The given scenario suggests Alopecia Areata in which geometric fine stippled pitting (Superficial, Regular, Fine) of nail is the most likely expected finding as shown below.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Thinning of nail:

 

  • Thinning of the nail, is not typically associated with alopecia areata. It is seen in lichen planus.


Option C. V shaped nicks on the edge of the nail:

 

  • V-shaped nicks on the edge of the nail are typically associated with Dariers disease.

 

 

Option D. Green nails:

 

  • Green nails are indicative of a Pseudomonas aeruginosainfection or green nail syndrome, are not associated with alopecia areata.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nail pitting is a common nail finding in patients with alopecia areata, an autoimmune disorder that also presents with patchy hair loss and characteristic exclamation mark hairs.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 89 Page No 89.28-33

questions.text: Nail Pitting in Psoriasis indicates involvement of?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Proximal Nail Matrix

 

Explanation:

 

  • Pits develop when the proximal nail matrix keratinized abnormally in a few spots, resulting in a concentration of parakeratotic cells in the superficial nail plate.

 

They appear as small punctate depressions of the superficial nail plate, which progress distally and often become more evident with nail growth.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nail Pitting in Psoriasis indicates involvement of Proximal Nail Matrix

 

Ref: Fitzpatrick’s Dermatology 8thEdition Page No 1014

questions.text: Koilonychia is seen in all the following conditions EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Megaloblastic Anaemia

 

Explanation:

 

Megaloblastic anemia does not result in koilonychia. Koilonychia describes a flattening or concavity of the nail's dorsal portion, creatingthe appearance of a spoon. It can occur in the following conditions:

 

  • Iron deficiency anaemia
  • Hemochromatosis
  • Raynaud’s disease.


The following image also shows koilonychia or spoon shaped nails:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Koilonychia is seen in Iron Deficiency Anaemia, Hemochromatosis, Raynaud’s Disease

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 95 Page No 95.7

questions.text: The following lines are NOT a pattern of apparent leukonychia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Beau's lines

 

Option B:

 

  • Beau's lines are generalised transverse grooves & indentations on the nail which is either full or of partial thickness.
  • They usually occur a few weeksafter the precipitating systemic event like MI, measles, mumps or pneumonia.
  • Beau's lines are not associated with leukonychia.
     

Beau's Lines / Transverse Grooves:

 

 

 

Explanation:


Option A. Muehrcke’s lines have multiple transverse white bands, parallel to lunula. They are specific finding of hypoalbuminemia. They are reversible with albumin infusion.

 

 

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muehrcke's_nails#/media/File:Muehrcke's_lines.JPG


Option C. Lindsay nails or half & halfnails. The proximal portion of the nail is white & the distal half is pink with a sharp line of demarcation between the two halves. They are specific for renal failure.

 

 

https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Lindsays_Nails_2.jpg


Option D. Terry’s nails that are entirely white except for a small band of pink or brown at the tip are Terry's nails.


Educational Objective:

 

  • Muehrcke’s Lines, Lindsay Nails, Terrys Nails are examples of Apparent Leukonychia
  • In Apparent Leukonychia, Pathology is predominant in the nail bed. These lines do not migrate with the growth of the nail.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 95 Page No 95.11, 95.14

questions.text: FALSE about Yellow Nail Syndrome & its associations?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pitting edema

 

Option D:

 

Yellow nail syndrome is associated with lymphedema which is non-pitting.

 

 

The classic triad of this uncommon disease includes:

 

  • Yellow Dystrophic Nails caused by nail thickening.
  • Primary Lymphedema (due to underdevelopment of the lymphatic vessels).
  • Pleural Edema

 

  • Other common manifestations include Chronic Rhinosinusitis, Chronic Bronchitis, Bronchiectasis, and increased risk of Malignancy.
  • Nephrotic Syndrome & D-Penicillamine Therapy are also associated with it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pitting edema is not a feature of Yellow Nail Syndrome; instead, the syndrome is characterized by yellow dystrophic nails, an increased risk of malignancy, pleural effusion, and typically non-pitting lymphedema.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 95 Page No 95.14

choices.text: Fingernails grow at speed of 3 mm/month
Lunula represents Distal Portion of Nail Matrix
Proximal Matrix forms Upper Nail Bed
Dorsal Pterygium is seen in Lichen Planus

questions.text: Which of the following statements is INCORRECT about our nails?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Proximal Matrix forms Upper Nail Bed

 

Option C: The proximal matrix is actually responsible for the formation of the upper part of the nail plate, not the nail bed.

 

 

The Distal Matrix forms lower Half ofNail Plate.
 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fingernails grow at a speed of 3 mm/month:
 

  • The average rate of fingernail growth is approximately 3 mm per month
  • Toenails grow even more slowly, typically 1 mm per month.
  • Hair grows at a rate of 10 mm per month.


Option B. Lunula represents the distal portion of the nail matrix:

 

The lunula is the visible part of the nail matrix which is the whitish, crescent-shaped base of the visible nail.

 

 

  • Lunula is present between proximal nail fold and nail bed and represents distal portion of nail matrix

 


Option D. Dorsal pterygium is seen in lichen planus:

 

  • Dorsal pterygium can be a consequence of the scarring process in lichen planus, a chronic inflammatory disease of the skin and mucous membranes.
  • Ventral pterygium is seen in connective tissue disorders like SLE and Systemic sclerosis.


Educational Objective:
 

  • The proximal matrix forms the upper part of the nail plate, not the upper nail bed, which is a key point in the anatomy of the nail.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 95.3, 95.10

questions.text: What is the nail finding seen in a patient of Hand Foot Mouth Disease (HFMD)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Onychomadesis

 

Option D: Onychomadesis is the finding associated with Hand Foot Mouth Disease (HFMD).

 

 

It is characterized by separation of the proximal part of the nail plate from the nail matrix and nail bed. This occurs due to a temporary arrest in nail matrix activity.
 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Clubbing:

 

  • Clubbing involves the swelling of the soft tissue at the nail base, leading to a change in the angle between the nail and the nail bed.

 

 

  • It is commonly associated with chronic cardiopulmonary conditions and is not a feature of HFMD.
     

Option B. Onycholysis:

 

  • Onycholysis is distal or lateral separation of nail plate from nail bed. It can result from trauma, infection, or psoriasis but is not typically seen in HFMD.
     

Option C. Pterygium:

 

  • Dorsal pterygium can be a consequence of the scarring process in lichen planus, a chronic inflammatorydisease of the skin and mucous membranes.

 

 

  • Ventral pterygium is seen in connective tissue disorders like SLE and Systemic sclerosis.


 

 

  • It is not a feature of HFMD.
     

Educational Objective:
 

  • Onychomadesis, the separation of the proximal nail plate from the nail matrix and bed, is a nail finding that can follow Hand Foot Mouth Disease (HFMD).

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 95.11

choices.text: The Causative Organism is Microsporumcanis
Proximal Subungual Onychomycosis is the Most common form
Investigation of Choice is Nail Culture
Distal Lateral Subungual Onychomycosis is commonly associated with HIV Patients

questions.text: Identify the CORRECT statement regarding Onychomycosis among the following options?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Investigation of choice is Nail culture

 

Option C:

 

  • To confirm the diagnosis of onychomycosis, nail culture is considered the gold standard as it allows for identification of the specific fungal organism responsible for the infection.Top of Form
     

Explanation:

 

Option A. The causative organism is Microsporumcanis:

 

  • Microsporumcanis primarily affects the hair and skin and is not typically the causative organism in onychomycosis as it spares Nails.
  • Onychomycosis is most commonly caused by dermatophytes like Trichophyton species but can also be due to yeasts such as Candida or non-dermatophyte molds.
     

Option B. Proximal Subungual Onychomycosis is the Most common form:

 

  • The most common form of onychomycosis is Distal Lateral Subungual Onychomycosis (DLSO), which usually presents with Yellowing, Thickening, and Subungual hyperkeratosis starting at the distal and lateralnail bed and progressing proximally.

 

 

  • Only subungual hyperkeratosis without tunnelling is seen in psoriasis
     

Option D. Distal Lateral Subungual Onychomycosis is commonly associated with HIV patients:

 

  • While Proximal Subungual Onychomycosis (PSO) is indeed more common in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV/AIDS, DLSO can occur in a variety of patients, not specifically associated with HIV.

 

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • The investigation of choice for diagnosing onychomycosis is nail culture, which helps identify the specific causative fungal organism.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 32.48

questions.text: Match the following Nail findings in Column A with Associated Causes / Diseases in Column B:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-c, 2-a, 3-b, 4-d

 

Correct matches:

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option 1. Mees' lines (c Arsenic poisoning):

 

  • Mees' lines are horizontal white lines on the nails and are classically associated with arsenic poisoning.

 

 

 

Option 2. Terry's Nails (a Cirrhosis):

 

  • Terry's nails are characterized by a white nail with a distal band of reddish-brown and can be seen in cirrhosis.

 

 

Option 3. Lindsay's Nails (b Chronic renal failure):

 

  • Lindsay's nails, also known as half-and-half nails, have a proximal white area and a distal pink or brown band and are commonly associated with chronic renal failure.

 

 

Option 4. Koilonychia (d Anemia):

 

  • Koilonychia, also known as spoon nails, is where the nails are concave in shape and can be associated with Iron Deficiency Anemia.
     

Educational Objective:
 

  • Mees' lines with arsenic poisoning, Terry's nails with cirrhosis, Lindsay's nails with chronic renal failure, and koilonychia with anemia.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 95.7, 95.14

questions.text: What is the level of pathology in the below image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nail Bed

 

Option B: Lindsay's nails, or half-and-half nails, have a distinct appearance with the proximal portion being white and the distal portion a normal pink or brown, which is due to pathology in the nail bed causing these color changes.

Explanation:

 

Option A. Nail Plate:

  • Image depicts Lindsay nails / Half and Half nails which is an example for apparent leukonychia and is seen associated with Chronic renal failure and the pathology is in the nail bed not Nail plate.
     

Option C. Distal Nail Matrix:

  • Incorrect as pathology in the distal nail matrix would affect the formation of the nail plate itself, leading to changes in the texture or thickness of the nail plate as it grows out.
     

Option D. Proximal Nail Matrix:

  • Incorrect because changes in the proximal nail matrix would typically affect the mostsuperficial part of the nail plate as it forms, not the nail bed.
     

Educational Objective:
 

  • The pathology in Lindsay's nails, known as half-and-half nails, is located in the nail bed, which manifests as a bicolored appearance of the nails.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 95.14

questions.text: Regular Pitting of Nails is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alopecia Areata

 

Option B: Alopecia areata can manifest with regular, superficial, and fine pitting of the nails, often resembling the surface of a thimble.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Psoriasis:

 

  • While nail pitting can indeed be seen in psoriasis, the pitting is typically irregular, deep, and coarse.

 

 

  • Psoriasis can cause a variety of nail changes, like onycholysis (nail bed separation), and subungual hyperkeratosis.
     

Option C. Lichen Planus:

 

  • Incorrect because lichen planus typically causes longitudinal ridging and thinning of the nail, pterygium.
  • Lichen planus can also lead to nail dystrophy or even loss of the nail plate.
     

Option D. Herpes Zoster:

 

  • Incorrect as herpes zoster, or shingles, affects the skin with vesicular eruptions following a dermatomal distribution.
  • It is not typically associated with nail changes.

 

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Regular, Superficial, and Fine Pitting of the nails is characteristic of Alopecia Areata, whereas Irregular, Deep, and Coarse Pitting is more indicative of psoriasis.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 89.28-33

questions.text: Trachyonychia is seen associated with all of the following conditions EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pemphigus

 

Option C: Pemphigus is an autoimmune blistering disorder and is not commonly associated with trachyonychia. Nail involvement in pemphigus is rare and usually involves the development of blisters or erosions rather than the roughness associated with trachyonychia.

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lichen Planus:

 

  • Trachyonychia, also known as "Twenty-nail dystrophy / Sand paper Nails," is commonly associated with lichen planus.
  • It is characterized by rough, opaque, and brittle nails as shown below.

 

 

Option B. Psoriasis:

 

  • Trachyonychia can also be seen in patients with psoriasis, a condition that can cause a multitude of nail changes including pitting, onycholysis, and the "oil drop" sign.
     

Option D. Alopecia Areata:

 

  • Trachyonychia is often seen in patients with alopecia areata and can be a clue to the diagnosis when hair loss is subtle or not yet apparent.
     

Educational Objective:
 

  • Trachyonychia is associated with conditions such as Lichen Planus, Psoriasis, andAlopecia Areata but not typically with pemphigus.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 37.12, 89.32, 95.11

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common manifestation of Nail Psoriasis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pitting

 

Option C: Nail pitting is the most common manifestation of nail psoriasis. It appears as small, pinpoint depressions on the nail surface.

 

 

  • The pitting is due to the psoriatic disruption of keratinocyte adhesion in the nail matrix.
     

Explanation:

 

Option A. Onycholysis:

 

  • Onycholysis is the separation of the nail from the nail bed and is seen in nail psoriasis, but it is not the most frequent feature.
  • It typically occurs in more severe cases and can be quite distressing to patients due to the functional impairment it can cause.


Option B. Yellow Discoloration:

 

  • Yellow discoloration is less common than pitting.
  • It represents a build-up of psoriatic material in the nail bed.


Option D. Subungual Hyperkeratosis:

 

  • Subungual hyperkeratosis is the accumulation of scales beneath the distal nail plate, which can lead to nail plate elevation and is seen in nail psoriasis, but pitting is more commonly the initial finding.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Nail pitting is the most common clinical manifestation of nail psoriasis, characterized by small, pinpoint depressions on the nail plate.

 

Ref: Fitzpatrick’s Dermatology 8thEdition Page No 1014

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 3-day history of pain and redness around her right thumbnail. She reports that the area is tender to touch and has progressively worsened. She denies any trauma or prior similar episodes. She works as a bartender and often has her hands in water. Examination reveals erythema, edema, and tenderness of the proximal nail fold, with some purulent discharge. Her temperature is 37.8°C (100°F). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute Paronychia

 

Option A:

 

  • Acute paronychia is an infection of the periungual tissue, often bacterial, characterized by rapid onset of pain, erythema, and swelling, possibly with purulent discharge.

 

 

  • It is commonly associated with water immersion or nail trauma.
     

Explanation:

 

Option B. Chronic Paronychia:

 

  • Incorrect because chronic paronychia is a prolonged inflammation of the periungual tissues, often multifactorial, associated with frequent immersion in water, irritants, or allergens.
  • It is characterized by less intensesymptoms over weeks to months, without significant purulent discharge.
     

Option C. Alopecia Areata:

 

  • Incorrect because alopecia areata is an autoimmune condition characterized by sudden hair loss in round patches on the scalp and other body parts, not associated with nail fold infection.
     

Option D. Psoriasis:

 

  • Incorrect because psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune skin disease with characteristic findings of silvery scales on erythematous plaques, which can involve nails causing pitting, onycholysis, or subungual hyperkeratosis, but not usually acute inflammation or purulent discharge.

 

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Diagnose acute paronychia based on the clinical presentation of rapid onset of pain, redness, and tenderness at the proximal nail fold, often with purulent discharge, typically associated with water exposure or trauma.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 95.35

questions.text: A 56-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus presents to the clinic complaining of discoloration of his fingernails over the past several months. He mentions that the nails have turned a greenish hue. He is a retired plumber and enjoys woodworking in his spare time. He denies any pain, trauma, or previous similar episodes but notes a mild, persistent odour. On examination, the nails are thickened with a greenish-black discoloration. There is no significant erythema or warmth, and the surrounding skin appears intact. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Green Nail Syndrome

 

Option C: Green Nail Syndrome:
 

  • Green nail syndrome, caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection, typically presents with greenish discoloration of the nail, which can be associated with a mild, distinct odor.

 

 

  • It often affects individuals with prolonged exposure to water, as could be the case with the patient's history of plumbing.
     

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute Paronychia:
 

  • Acute paronychia presents with rapid onset of pain, erythema, and swelling, often with purulent discharge, which is not consistent with the chronic discoloration and absence of acute inflammatory signs described in the vignette.
     

Option B. Onychomycosis:
 

  • Onychomycosis typically presents as thickening, yellowing, and crumbling of the nail, without the characteristic greenish discoloration that is described in the patient's presentation.
     

Option D. Subungual Hematoma:
 

  • Subungual hematoma typically presents with a painful, red to black discoloration under the nail following trauma, which is not consistent with the chronic, painless, greenish discoloration in this patient.
     

Educational Objective:
 

  • Diagnose green nail syndrome based on a characteristic greenish nail discoloration, potentially with a mild Odor, without significant inflammatory signs, in a patient with risk factors such as prolonged water exposure or occupations such as plumbing.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 26.52

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with a history of chronic kidney disease presents to the clinic for a routine follow-up. She has no new complaints and feels well with her current management plan. On examination, you notice several transverse white bands across her fingernails as shown below and blanch when pressure is applied to the nail plate. She is concerned about the appearance of her nails and asks if this signifies a worsening of her condition. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Muehrckes Bands

 

Option C: Muehrckes bands are paired, white transverse lines that appear stationary and are typically associated with hypo-albuminemia, which can be seen in patients with chronic kidney disease.

 

 

 

  • They do not move with nail growth and disappear with pressure, indicating they are in the vascular nail bed, not the nail plate.
     

Explanation:


Option A. Terry's nails:

 

  • Terrys nails typically present as a white nail plate with a distal band of reddish-brown and are associated with liver cirrhosis, which is not the pattern described.
     

Option B. Beau's lines:

 

  • Beau's lines are transverse indentations that move distally with nail growth and can be associated with any condition that causes a temporary cessation of nail growth, such as severe illness.

 

 

Option D. Onychomycosis:

 

  • Onychomycosis is a fungal infection of the nail plate that presents with thickening, discoloration, and sometimes separation of the nail from the nail bed, which does not describe the transverse white bands seen in this patient.
     

    Why it is not Lindsay Nails (Half-and-Half Nails):

    Although Lindsay nails are associated with chronic kidney disease, this image is not consistent with Lindsay nails because:

  • Lindsay nails show a proximal white area and a distal brownish-red band, often separated by a sharp line. In contrast, this image shows multiple paired white bands across the nail, not the half-and-half appearance.

Educational Objective:
 

  • Muehrckes bands is paired, stationarywhite lines on the nails, indicative of underlying systemic conditions like hypoalbuminemia, particularly in patients with chronic kidney disease.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 95.14

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of redness and swelling around her nail folds. She reports tenderness, especially when pressure is applied, and occasional pus drainage from around her nails. She works as a dishwasher and frequently has her hands in soapy water. Physical examination reveals erythema and edema around several nail folds, and the cuticle is no longer visible. There is no evidence of fever or deep tissue infection. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chronic Paronychia

 

Option C: Chronic paronychia is an inflammatory disorder of the nail folds which can persist for weeks to months and is often associated with occupational water exposure.

 

 

  • Loss of the cuticle barrier allows irritants and allergens to perpetuateinflammation.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Acute Paronychia:

 

  • Acute paronychia is a rapid-onset condition, usually painful, and often associated with pus accumulation.
  • It typically resolves quickly with treatment, which does not align with the chronic course described.


Option B. Onychomycosis:

 

  • Onychomycosis is a fungal infection of the nails, generally characterized by thickening, discoloration, and nail dystrophy, not primarily by inflammation of the nail folds.


Option D. Herpetic Whitlow:

  • Herpetic whitlow is a painful viral infection caused by herpes simplex virus, presenting with grouped vesicles on an erythematous base, typically on the fingertip, not as a chronic condition affecting the nail folds.
     

Educational Objective:

 

  • The signs and symptoms of chronic paronychia, includes persistent inflammation of the nail folds, tenderness, and possible pus discharge, often related to prolonged exposure to moisture, as seen in individuals who frequently have their hands in water.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 95.36

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man comes to the clinic for a follow-up visit after being hospitalized for severe pneumonia 2 months ago. He has recovered well and has no respiratory symptoms. However, he has noticed horizontal indentations across all of his fingernails, which he reports appeared after his hospitalization. He is concerned about these new nail changes and is curious about what they might indicate.

Examination reveals transverse grooves across the nails, which the patient confirms are non-painful. Examination of rest of the body did not show any evidence of skin lesions. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the nail changes in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Systemic Illness

 

Option C: Beau's lines are horizontal indentations that form on the nails due to a temporary interruption of nail growth.

 

 

  • They can be caused by any severe systemic illness that disturbs nail keratinization, such as a severe infection, which aligns with the patient's recent severe pneumonia.
     

Explanation:

 

Option A. Chronic Renal Failure:

 

  • While chronic renal failure can cause various nail changes, including half-and-half nails (Lindsay’s nails), it is not typically associated with the formation of transverse grooves or lines across the nails.
     

Option B. Psoriasis:

 

  • Psoriasis can cause nail changes, including pitting, onycholysis, and subungual hyperkeratosis, but the transverse grooves described, known as Beau's lines, are not specific to psoriasis and are typically related to an interruption in nail growth due to systemic illness.
     

Option D. Fungal Nail Infection:

 

  • Fungal nail infection, or onychomycosis, usually presents as thickening, discoloration, and separation of the nail from the nail bed, not as transverse grooves across the nails.
     

Educational Objective:
 

  • Beau's lines is transverse indentations that can appear on the nails following a temporary interruption of nail growth due to systemic illnesses, such as severe infections.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 95.11

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used as nail lacquer belongs to morpholines?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Amorolfine

 

Option A:

 

  • Amorolfine is a morpholine that is available as a 5% nail lacquer. Amorolfine inhibits two separate stages in the synthesis of ergosterol and is fungicidal.
  • It is used in the treatment of onychomycosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Oxiconazole:

 

  • This is an azoleantifungal drug.
  • Azoles work by inhibiting the enzyme lanosterol 14-α-demethylase, which is crucial in converting lanosterol to ergosterol.


Option C. Ciclopirox Olamine:

 

  • Ciclopirox is a hydroxypyridone antifungal agent, not a morpholine.

 

 

 

  • It acts by chelating polyvalent cations, resulting in the inhibition of the metal-dependent enzymes responsible for the degradation of peroxides within fungal cells.
     

Option D. Tioconazole:

 

  • Tioconazole is another azoleantifungal agent and, like oxiconazole, works by inhibiting ergosterol synthesis.
     

Educational Objective:
 

  • Amorolfine is the only morpholine derivative among the options given, used as a nail lacquer for the treatment of fungal infections.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 18 Page No 18.12

Online resources: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20737634/

https://ijdvl.com/onychomycosis-diagnosis-and-management/

questions.text: A 38-year-old male comes with complaints in his fingernail. On examination, nail folds were seen to be erythematous & with pus collection as shown in the picture. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Paronychia
 

Option A:

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Yellow Nail Syndrome:

 

  • Description: A rare condition characterized by slow growing, thickened, yellow nails as shown in the below image.

 

 

  • Symptoms: Besides the characteristic yellow nails, the syndrome may also present with lymphedema (swelling due to lymphatic obstruction) and respiratory manifestations.
  • Causes: The exact cause is unknown, but it's associated with chronic sinusitis, rheumatoid arthritis, and certain cancers.
     

Option C. Psoriasis:

 

  • Description: A chronic inflammatory skin condition.
  • Symptoms: Nail psoriasis can cause pitting, abnormal nail growth, and discoloration.
     

Option D. Alopecia Areata:

 

  • Description: An autoimmune disease where the body attacks its own hair follicles, resulting in hair loss.
  • Symptoms: Sudden patchy hair loss in small, round patches on the scalp or body. Nails can also be affected, showing pits (which are superficial regular & Fine as shown in the below image), white spots, roughness, or a sandpaper-like texture.
     

 

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Paronychia is a condition presenting with Erythematous and Edematous nail folds, often accompanied by pus collection, commonly resulting from bacterial infection.

 

Ref: Fitzpatrick’s Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Chapter 150 Page No 2725

Andrews Diseases of the Skin Clinical Dermatology 11thEdition Chapter 14, Page No 248

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Chapter 95 Page No 95.35

questions.text: Irregular pitting of the nails with subungual hyperkeratosis is seen in?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Psoriasis

 

Option B: Irregular pitting of the nails with subungual hyperkeratosis is most commonly seen in psoriasis, which is a chronic inflammatory skin condition.

 

Psoriasis:

 

  • It is an inflammatory non-infectious disease characterized by an imbalance in T-cell subsets. There is an elevated number of activated Th1, Th17, and Th22 cells, while Th2 cells are deficient.
     

Cytokines in psoriasis:

 

 

  • Genetic Predisposition: In Type 1plaque psoriasis and guttatepsoriasis with HLAC: 06:02 association.
  • Around 5-30% of individuals with cutaneous psoriasis also develop psoriatic arthritis (PsA), a condition affecting the joints.
    • Psoriasis can affect the skin and joints, leading to psoriatic arthritis.
    • About 5-30% of patients with cutaneous psoriasis have psoriatic arthritis (PsA).
    • At any given time, 40% of psoriasis cases have changes to their nails.
    • Nail psoriasis is linked to more severe psoriasis, longer disease duration, psoriatic arthritis, and family history of the condition.

 

Nail changes in psoriasis:

 

 

 

  • Salmon patches or subungual oil drop sign is extremely specific pathognomonic sign of nail psoriasis. It looks like an oildroplet and is a yellowish, reddishdiscoloration in the nail bed.
  • However, the most frequent symptom is nail pitting.
  • Individual pits are irregular in shape and uniform in depth. These nail pits, also referred to as Thimblepits, are brought on by the proximalnailmatrix's involvement.
  • Subungualhyperkeratosis, splinterhemorrhages, and distalonycholysis are additional symptoms of nail bed disease.
  • There might also be leukonychia.

 

 

Pitting affecting the fingernails

 

 

Onycholysis along with pitting and salmon patches in fingernails

 

 

Leukonychia in a patient with psoriasis

 

 

Nail plate thickening and crumbling resulting in complete nail dystrophy

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis–Mnemonic

 

"Nail - POLISH"

  • P – Pitting (Most common feature)
  • O – Oil drop sign (Pathognomonic), Onycholysis
  • L – Leukonychia
  • I – Irregular pitting pattern
  • S – Splinter Haemorrhage
  • H – Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lichen Planus:

 

  • Lichen planus can affect the nails and produce nail changes, but the common manifestations are nail thinning, ridging, or even complete loss of the nail.
  • Pterygium formation, where there's scarring of the cuticle area leading to the nail's progressive loss, can also be seen.
  • While lichen planus can cause nail pitting, it's typically not associated with subungual hyperkeratosis, a feature more consistent with psoriasis.

 

Option C. Vitiligo:

 

  • Vitiligo is a disorder where there's a loss of pigment-producing cells (melanocytes) leading to white patches on the skin.
  • It doesn't typically produce pitting of nails.

 

Option D.Alopecia Areata:

 

  • Geometric fine stippled pitting (Superficial, Regular, Fine) of the nails is the most likely expected finding as shown below.
     

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Psoriasis is the condition most commonly associated with irregular nail pitting and subungual hyperkeratosis among the options provided.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Page No 4.9, 35.4-35.34, 37.12, 41.1, 41.21 89.28-33

Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20thEdition Page No 333

questions.text: Which of the following is commonly associated with the condition shown below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pitting of Nails

 

Explanation:

 

Option C: The given scenario suggests alopecia areata in which geometric fine stippled pitting (Superficial, Regular, Fine) of nail is the most likely expected finding as shown below

 

 

Alopecia areata:
 

  • Alopecia areata is a chronic Autoimmune disease that causes non scaringpatches of hair loss.
  • It is a T cell mediatedinflammatory disease that occurs in genetically predisposed individuals. Pigmented hair is more frequently affected in alopecia areata.
  • Grey hair in older patients often includes both white and coloured hair. Only coloured hair will be impacted by the disease if it advances quickly, sparing white hair. This leads to a dramatic change in overall hair colour that is called going white overnight.
     

 

The following image sparing of white hair within patches of hair loss.

 

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Nail changes are common in alopecia areata, with nail pitting being the most frequent finding.
  • Nail pitting appears as small depressions on the nail surface.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 89 Page No 89.28-33

questions.text: The image shown below is a pathognomonic finding in Psoriasis. What is it called?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subungual Oil Drop Sign

 

Option B: Salmon patches or subungual oil drop sign is extremely specific pathognomonicsign of nail psoriasis. It looks like an oil droplet and is a yellowish, reddish discoloration in the nail bed.

 

Psoriasis:

 

  • It is an inflammatory noninfectious disease. There is an increased number of activated Th1, Th17&Th22 cells with a deficiency of Th2 cells.
  • Genetic predisposition is present in type 1 plaque psoriasis & guttate psoriasis with HLA C: 06: 02
  • About 5-30% of patients with cutaneous psoriasis have psoriatic arthritis (PsA).
  • At any given time, 40% of psoriasis cases have changes to their nails. Nail psoriasis is linked to more severe psoriasis, longer disease duration, psoriatic arthritis, and family history of the condition.
     

Nail changes in psoriasis:

 

  • Salmon patches or subungual oil drop sign is extremely specific pathognomonic sign of nail psoriasis.
  • It looks like an oil droplet and is a yellowish, reddish discoloration in the nail bed.
  • However, the most frequent symptom is nail pitting (Option A)
  • Individual pits are irregular in shape and uniform indepth. These nail pits, also referred to as Thimble pits, are brought on by the proximal nail matrix's involvement.
  • Subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter haemorrhages, and distal onycholysis are additional symptoms of nail bed disease.
  • There might also be leukonychia.

 

 

Pitting affecting the fingernails

 

 

Onycholysis along with pitting and salmon patches in fingernails

 

 

Leukonychia in apatientwith psoriasis

 

 

Nail plate thickening and crumbling resulting in complete nail dystrophy.

 

Features of Nail Psoriasis–Mnemonic

 

"Nail - POLISH"

 

  • P – Pitting (Most common feature)
  • O–Oil drop sign (Pathognomonic), Onycholysis
  • L–Leukonychia
  • I –Irregular pitting pattern
  • S–Splinter Haemorrhage
  • H–Hyperkeratosis (Subungual)

 

Explanation:

 

Option D. Nail Pterygium:

 

  • It is the most specific nail change in Lichen planus. Fusion of proximal nail fold and nail bed with destruction of nail plate, leads to pterygium as shown in the below image.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Subungual oil drop sign is a specific clinical finding in nail psoriasis, which presents as a yellow to orange discoloration under the nail plate, distinguishing it from other nail changes such as pitting, thinning, or pterygium.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 35 Page No 35.4-35.6, 35.9

Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 20thEdition Page No 333
